It was too long ago to remember. When I left school at... When I was 16 and wanted to be a writer then, I guess it was something that I always enjoyed doing as a kid at school. You know, the essays and the story writing exercises you get. And when I left school, I told the world I was going to be a writer. And it seemed a good idea until somebody said, well, with all the accumulated wisdom and experience of 16 years, what are you going to write about that the world is breathlessly waiting to hear? And I hadn't thought about that. The answer was not a lot. So I went away into engineering and electronics and computers and things like that for something like 20 years. And I suppose the interest in writing probably never went away. And 20-odd years later, that situation had changed a lot. I'd spent a lot of that time. I started off as an electronics engineer and then a computer designer and then went into selling computer systems. And not the blue boxes you see at work that print out payrolls and things. I'm not talking about business computers, but the real-time scientific systems that might go into scientific research laboratories connected up to instruments to collect all the data and turn them into pictures on screens and the sort of computers you'd find in particle accelerator installations or observatories. In other words, all my customers were scientists, physicists, biologists, chemists, and so forth. And the kinds of systems we're talking about ranged up to several million dollars. And when somebody's buying a system of that size, it's not the kind of thing that you sell in a one-half-hour sales call and, say, sign the paper. you're frequently working with them for 12, maybe 18 months before a contract is finalized. During that time, you have to try and understand a lot of what they're doing in terms of being able to put together and recommend the right sort of system for their needs. In other words, you get to know a little bit of what they're all doing. I found it fascinating, a fascinating world that they lived in. the you also get to know them socially how they think how they tick what makes them laugh very interesting as people and I found 20 years later that there were a lot of interesting things to put here to write about and form the basis of stories so I didn't particularly set out to be a science fiction writer I suppose I became one by accident I just always wanted to write and started writing stories about the little bit of life that I'd had some personal experience of and was told I was a science fiction writer, and I said, how's that? They said, well, the publisher is publishing it under their science fiction influence, so we guess you have to be, so I said okay. And it kind of started out like that. Oh, okay. Yeah. Well, that provided more the trigger. The stimulation to take an interest in that kind of work, I guess reading provided a lot of it. But that kind of material is easy to read when you have a vested interest in understanding it because you have business relationships that will profit from that understanding In other words, it's reading with a purpose, a clear-cut purpose rather than just out of curiosity or a way of killing time. But luckily, it became a little more than that. Do you usually do a lot of—back up here. Most of your stories, I guess, would be called hard science fiction. Yeah. Do you do a lot of research whenever you do write a story? Yeah, I do. I read quite a lot, and I suppose the bulk of my reading is non-fiction, so even casual reading in a way becomes what might be termed non-specific research. In other words, information that just gets stored away and comes out later, although I didn't study it for any particular reason at the time. But before I became a full-time writer, I was still working in the computer business, I made use of my customers pretty freely as consultants, which was kind of handy. I found that I had customers who were brain surgeons and other customers who studied pieces of rock brought back from the Apollo missions and other guys who were building or investigating machine intelligence. And just about any of the topics, or the favorite themes of science fiction that you could tick out of a hat, the chances were sort of not ten to one. I had a customer specializing in that field, and I just had to... If I needed some background information on a particular topic, I could almost guarantee I had a phone number in my diary of the guy who could talk all day about it. And they loved doing it, as well. I used to call them, and if they'd like to come and talk to you tomorrow, Well we're a little busy but what's it about? Oh I need some help with the book I'm working on. Well why didn't you say so? What time do you want to show up? And they talk all day. And I think this is one of the interesting sides of selling computers into this kind of area. You can imagine some of these specialists they talk to bacteria all day long or whatever and they end up shut in the back rooms of universities. And maybe there are four people on the planet they can talk to who understand their language. And sometimes they find it hard to believe that somebody from the world outside that has walked in off the street is sincerely interested to sit down and talk to them and is curious, and he wants to know what they're doing, wants to have it explained. And it was a very pleasant way to worth living, you not only, you know, gain customers in many instances, I found you gain friends as well. It was a very pleasant combination to build a life around with, the things you like doing, the kind of work that you like to the kind of activity that you like to do is also part of a process of making friends and not only that somebody's prepared to pay you to do it I found that a very pleasant situation Your first novel, in fact I believe it was the first thing that you wrote was in A Hair of the Stars it's a science fiction detective story Yes. How did you come to write that book? Well, I think that sums it up pretty well. It reflects, I think, the way I see science, which is indeed as a wonderful, ongoing, never-ending detective story. and I suppose I got a little bit dissatisfied with some of the depictions of science and scientists that I'd seen in fiction. I formed the impression or the suspicion in some cases that perhaps the people who had written some of the fiction certainly would have perhaps not worked in a scientific field or spoken to a scientist for a long, long time and maybe generations of people had reinforced each other's clichés. Scientists were always eccentric and they wore odd-coloured shoes and they drew cabbages that ate people and they wanted to conquer the world or something. There were these cute public impressions of scientists just as people who run down the street with no clothes off, shouting Eureka, or, you read phrases like, it came to him in a flash, and you read on, and what came to him in a flash would have been enough to keep Einstein busy for the next 20 years, and real science, yeah, there are insights, There are strokes of genius, but the overwhelming bulk of the work is done by a lot of unsung heroes, a lot of people doing nothing really dramatic or exciting, but just meticulously sifting through details and collecting information for generations and for centuries or different parts of the world. And it's really like putting together a huge jigsaw puzzle, Lots of people cutting out pieces and twisting them around. Every now and again somebody will take a huge chunk in this corner and see that it fits with a huge chunk down there. And that's a breakthrough. And so it goes on. And it really is a detective story. I think it's a far more exciting one than most detective fiction. And I wanted to write a story that attempted to depict it in this kind of way and hopefully would convey some of the excitement that personally I feel when I look at this whole scene. Yeah, I believe... I think that... I thought that, yeah, let's make it a detective story, but if we... If we want a detective mystery that is going to be sufficiently intriguing to motivate a large proportion of the scientific community as happened in Inherit the Stars, we want something a little more original and exciting than bodies in the library or footprints in the flower bed. So we invented Charlie and the aliens, and the rest I suppose you know. Basically it was an attempt to depict science as it is, or at least as I perceive it. And at the same time weave that into a story that people who were non-scientists, non-specialists, would find stimulating and arousing for the curiosity even if, you know, without trying to turn it into a 250-page lab report or something like that. Yeah, I believe, I don't know if I'm reading this into your work or not, but some of what I'm feeling is that your writing is sort of almost a celebration of learning, you know, the learning process. Yes. I think it's one of the most exciting processes anybody can experience. I think it's very sad that in large sections of our culture we should have evolved the attitude that learning is something you endure until you leave school, and then it ceases without output. I think education and living are just different aspects of the same process that never ends in the minds of a lot of people the two things seem to have separated out and for some reason learning is looked upon as hard work and something that you you steer clear of unless you can't avoid it I think that's very very sad no reason why it should be so it's just a consequence of cultural expectations a lot of people expect it to be hard work and tedious and sure enough it is. In your stories, I've noticed that you really flesh out the futures that you create with a lot of detail. Uh-huh. I lost my question. You were saying about the future of detail. I don't know that there's any particular purpose in doing that. And he opens up his briefcase and plugs in his video phone to the plane and makes this long-distance call right there. It seems so natural that it just creates a very realistic atmosphere for your story. Yeah, I like to do things like that. I see what you mean by detail now. I think these kinds of details do matter because if we're putting a story into a futuristic setting, I think these little details of background, such as if the guy needs to make a phone tour, how does he go about it if he needs to rent a cab? these matter because if the story is being told in the future the whole of the background has to be consistently futuristic I've come across a number of instances which in my opinion are a little flawed because felt with an A.W. A writer may have seized on a particular thought, maybe a new scientific idea or a machine or whatever. Develops that very well, but kind of gets hung up on it and in the background, everything else that's going on hasn't changed since 1980. And trying to, I think, just stop typing for the five minutes it takes just to think about a situation. The guy's going to make a phone call just like stop and think how he might make that and think about it for five minutes and then maybe show it in a way different to what would have been the impulsive thing to do in the first couple of seconds. It's worth the effort. I don't think it radically changes the story, but it does give it that finishing polish, as it were, at least in that sense. And I try to do this in all the stories, and I find that readers like it. I think I, from the people who write to me and the people that I meet, one of the gratifying things I observe in the readership that I have is that very, it is not confined to what might be termed a hardcore science fiction reader who buys anything new that appears on the science fiction section of the bookstores. But a lot of, I suppose, people who might be termed younger professional people in their late 20s, 30s, 40s, in all manner of professions, not necessarily to do with the sciences, teachers, lawyers, doctors, so forth, who typically would say, gee, I used to read science fiction when I was at college or when I was at university, but I kind of grew out of it. I can't relate to way out galaxies like years away anymore or aliens running around with ray guns today I have a family, a career a mortgage, my feet are solidly on the surface of this planet but they seem to like stories that don't kind of try and take them to the other side of the universe a million years from now but maybe just stretch the future 20 or 30 years and they find names in the book like IBM and Davis and Boeing familiar places, and it grabs them. I say, well, this I can relate to. It's the world that I live in just stretched a little bit. The connection is not broken. The economics and the politics have evolved from what I read in the papers. I can still see the connections, and it could be the world my kids grow up in. And I like it, and if it has that effect on that, you know, far vast and a market of readership, then I'm perfectly happy to continue doing that, in addition to the reason that I enjoy the stories better myself for doing that. I wouldn't be misreading and saying you're an optimistic person, would I? I think I am. I notice your stories tend to be rather optimistic. Sure. Why not? Good question. Why not? I think there's enough doom and gloom around. I try and contribute something to counterbalance all that. I think it's needed. You probably would hold a great hope for the human potential then. Excuse me? I missed a question. You probably would hold a great hope for the human potential. Oh, I think it's unlimited. it doesn't guarantee we'll use it correctly and wisely. There's no guarantee of that, but I have no doubt that the potential exists and the choice is entirely up to us. And I think that in itself is grounds for optimism. It means that we're not pawns that are pushed around by fate or magical mystical forces that we have no control over our future. I think that would be a very depressing thought. I think it underlies a lot of the philosophies that we hear expounded. You know, an excuse to quit trying, to write everything off as futile. I don't subscribe to this at all. I think that in the same way that the individual's future lies in his or her hands, and I think they have infinite potential to build upon if they have a, I think the only resource that we're short of in some quarters is positive thinking and the right attitude of mind. Nothing else. And I think collectively the same is true. I think that there is a human tendency to be too conscious of our failings and our faults and our mistakes, which have happened. It would be silly to deny that. And I think, by and large, we've achieved some remarkable and wonderful things as well and continue to do so. Yes. To itself, 24 hours in the past. Sure. And then, by that process, just keep sending it back to itself and back to itself. Uh-huh. I've been reading recently about several scientists who are speculating about real possibilities of time travel. Yeah. Was your novel... Your novel really was written before those came out. It's sort of prophetic in a way. Maybe that's where they got it from. Well, I don't know whether it's prophetic or not. Well, as is elaborated in the book itself, if something like that ever became a fact, there are some pretty interesting problems that are going to have to be solved, and our ideas of logic and cause and effect are going to have to undergo some pretty interesting revisions. So I'm certainly not setting myself up as a prophet and saying, yes, it'll happen. Maybe. I don't know. I think history has shown that impossible or it'll never happen are very dangerous phrases to use in any context. As far as I was concerned, it was just a fun basis for a story, certainly not an original one. Although I did, I was trying, I don't suppose any of the things I've written about have been original in essence. I try and approach them from hopefully fresh and different angles. But for some time, And for a number of years, in fact, before I wrote Thrice Upon a Time, I'd been wanting to write a Time Shavet book for a number of reasons. Firstly, I wanted to attempt to face up to the paradoxes, the logical paradoxes, once and for all, and answer them without cop-outs, without convenient coincidences, and without obliging characters who just happen to do the right thing to make everything come out the way the author said. And secondly, I wanted to get away from this kind of cliche of some kind of a conjurer's box described or disguised as whatever that you jump into and you jump out of and you're in some other time. We've seen too many conjurer's boxes, and it seemed to me unrealistic. If I ever build a box like that, and I thought it was going to take me to another time, I certainly wouldn't jump into it and press the button. I would conduct a long series of tests and experiments first, and none of that heroes ever seem to do this. And it seemed to me reasonable to say, if we're going to make the speculation of influencing the past, it seemed to me to be reasonable to speculate that if we're going to make that assumption anyway, that before we move structured objects and people back into another time, we probably learn how to inject energy first. And if you can send energy back in time, you can obviously switch the energy on and off and modulate it and send information. In other words, you can send messages to yourself if you like. I didn't want it to be a million years or a billion years or in some huge span of time where really nothing that you did could make any difference. How about a lab bench experiment? Ten minutes. You can just send a little signal back to yourself. Ten minutes ago would change what you've already done. This is interesting. You're hard up against the paradoxes now. You can't find a way around them or duck them. You've got to answer the question, what happened? But the logic of it, the whole situation becomes absolutely, it drives you to the point of insanity trying to figure it out. I found the only way to do it was to think in terms of the simplest possible lab bench experiment that you could devise and strip away all the complications to just get the logic right and then elaborate it back in up to the level that would make a story interesting. And the simplest situation that you can think of is a button and a lamp. and when you push the button, the lamp comes on. It couldn't get much simpler than that. The only different thing here is the lamp comes on 10 seconds before you press the button because the signal goes back in time. So the question is obvious. What happens? I wait until the lamp comes on. 10 seconds later, it's time to press the button. You're not going to press it. Nobody could make me. I didn't want mystical forces compelling people to do something they didn't want to do. I wanted to preserve human free will. So what happens? I don't press it up. Conversely, I can say, well, the lamp didn't come on. But I'm going to press it up anyway, just to hell of it. What happened? So those are two situations. One being the inverse of the other. And if you can explain what happens, you can answer any time travel paradox because every one is an elaboration of one of those situations or the other. And it's not good enough to, for example, to wait for the lamp to come on and you say, you're not going to press the button and you fold your arms and sit there. And just as the time is up, the door opens and somebody strolls in and says, hey, what's this? And presses the button. That doesn't get you out of it because you're a scientist. you're going to repeat your experiment under conditions where that couldn't happen. You'd lock the door and set it up again. You'd go out of the room and have the computer press the button. But eventually you would test it time and time and time again. And if accidents happened that got you out of a mess the first time, you could eliminate them the next time. And eventually you have to face up to that question, what happened? That's what I wanted to do. And the third thing I wanted to do was to tell a story in which the time machine itself and the staggering conceptual changes in physics and philosophy that are implied are relevant to the story that's being told they're an integral part of it if you took them away there wouldn't be any story I think in too many stories time machines are used like starships they're just a device a vehicle to get characters into an unusual environment and then tell a pretty routine story that was stolen from Greek mythology or European medieval history. And the technology doesn't come into the story at all. They could have gone there on a greyhound bus. I didn't want to do that. And so the story was about some physicists who had stumbled upon this phenomenon and had realized that if what they were seeing meant what they thought it meant, it meant that they could actually inject information into the past, change the past, with all the questions that implies. And they proceeded to test this phenomenon and have paid some very, very strange results. And yet they're convinced that behind all this, there is some consistent system of super logic that does make sense, and they're trying to figure out the rules of it. And of course there's an unspoken or unwritten invitation for the reader to participate. And again, I suppose it's a kind of a detective story. Not so much a whodunit, but how is it done? Did you intend to follow the story in Inherit the Stars with a sequel, or was that from reader demand or what? A bit of both. When I wrote Inherit the Stars, I had three books in mind. I had a trilogy in mind. So I put the hooks in. Although Inherit the Stars was a complete story in itself, it didn't leave the reader hanging. It started and told and finished a story. Nevertheless, there were a couple of hooks in there that invited some questions, which sort of, as it were, paved the way to a follow-up book. And my thinking at the time was, I'll go that far, but I won't write the second book until I have some feedback as to how the readers liked the first one. And I got a lot of mail and they all liked it, and a lot of them said in their letters, will there be a follow-up, they picked out the hooks, so I wrote The Gentle Giants. And they wanted another one, and I did have a trilogy in mind when I wrote it, and the third one in that series is now written. It's called Giant Star, and it's a July title, so it should start to appear in the bookstores around June. It's the third and last. Yeah, I'm working on the, as I say, Giants nossas will be out in June, July, and I'm currently working on the one after that, which I don't have a title for yet because I always think of the title as last. And I don't know when it'll be on sale because I don't know when I'll finish it. Probably sometime this spring. What type of story is it without giving away any of the plot details? How can we sum it up? The background to the story is that we're in the second half of the next century. And some decades previously, in other words, around the year 2020, company a robot star probe was sent out programmed to tour a number of stars and simply to search for habitable planets and generally explore send down surface probes atmospheric probes things like that radio everything back and the political situation on earth was looking very very grave at that time I am an optimist but I can still invent World War III scenarios for a story you know it's fiction after all the optimism may turn out to be unjustified yet but towards the closing years of this project In other words, obviously, you don't build a ship like that overnight. When it was well along the way towards being completed, it was modified to be capable of making people. Let me qualify that. It's a strange thing to say. We read a lot of stories about starships that go on long voyages that take maybe centuries, and inevitably they've got frozen bodies or bodies in suspended animation or something like that. When you think about it, it seems rather an inefficient way to say, you know, you're not doing anything, the machines can fly the ship, the computers can get it there. The people aren't doing anything about, except, you know, just lying there freezing, so, you know, why not let the machines fly the ship and make the people when you get there? if we look at the progress made in molecular biology of genetic engineering in the last couple of decades, we already manufactured quite complex organic molecules to specifications such as drugs and certainly anesthetics. If we just extrapolate that a little further, who's to say you couldn't make a complete set of human DNA? In other words, instead of sending bodies and all the luck support equipment to freeze them and taking up all the space? Why not just store all the genetic information necessary to make people electronically in the computers and create them when you have found a planet that the instruments say they could survive on. And, you know, let's imagine for the sake of argument that 10 light years away you found a planet. Well, if the robots should have got there and sent back a signal saying started the experiment. Well, 10 years later, the signal gets to Earth. And even if they responded instantly, the ship's been in orbit for 20 years doing nothing, just waiting for a reply. Well, the ultimate test of whether or not a planet is inhabitable is to set up a colony and try it. And so we could have used those 20 years. So here's the interesting possibility of a race that evolves from a first generation of embryos that were created and nurtured and raised by computers and robots, a machine-raised race. And when you think about it, the relationship between the children and the machines does not really have to be a cold and sinister one at all. It could be quite a charming and amusing one. and the interesting thoughts that the book starts to play with is here's a race of kids that are being raised by some very rational, direct down to earth entities who don't double talk or deceive or have all these layers of human game playing that we have to contend with and they're not being raised completely without any exposure to the conditioning of conditioned adults with their prejudices and hatreds and taboos and a lot of the other nonsenses that make life so complicated in our society. And also, I mean, they're not a primitive society. They're a very high-technology society. They arrive with some of the most advanced equipment and technology ever devised while they were in orbit and growing up through infancy the machines were down on the surface preparing surface bases manufacturing facilities and industries and so forth by the time they actually enter adolescence the races the generations I should say that follow thereafter all of their material needs are provided by by highly automated means that in terms of their productivity relative to their numbers, everyone is a millionaire. And let's imagine that a mission from Earth eventually shows up, virtually... a big mission, a twenty year voyage maybe, so we're talking about a space ship that that maybe houses 20,000 people, virtually a space colony with engines, with its government, its military, its church organizations, its commercial institutions, the whole of society in miniature with its time-proved mechanisms for controlling and subordinating a population, which traditionally a ruling elite through history has imposed itself by restricting the flow of wealth and by offering protection either from real or imagined threats? So how do you control a race of millionaires who don't need your wealth? And the idea of restricting anything has never occurred to them, of restricting the supply of anything. They don't need you to protect them from anybody. And none of the tricks or the psychology or the scare tactics work. So, what happens when a race of machine-raised people eventually collides with a race of people-raised people? And that's really what the story is all about. Alright, let's hold for just a second. In your novel Two Faces of Tomorrow you explore the future of machine intelligence How far away do you think we might be from intelligent computers? I don't know that I have an answer to that Two Faces was not intended to be prophetic in any way nothing that I write in the fictional sense is I simply sketch possibilities of what might be, not predictions of what will be. Putting a time limit on, it's an awkward thing to be asked to do. While I'm sort of thinking about this, my mind is going back over the number of confident predictions that have been made in the past on various topics that prove disastrously wrong either one way or the other? I see no reason in principle why artificial systems of some kind not necessarily what we'd call computers in other words electronics of some form inside a box of some form that simply man-made system should not in principle be capable of all of the feats that are performed by the human mind in other words thinking in the sense that we normally use the word and all its connotations in everyday conversation we have a system already in existence a physical system that can think, the human brain itself we could turn the question around a little and say if the human brain is a physical system that can think is there any reason to suppose that some other system shouldn't be capable of doing likewise? And I see my answer is absolutely no reason why not. All right. I don't see anything unique that sets the human brain. I think the question really, it becomes metaphysical. I think the question, what's lurking behind or beneath the surface of this whole debate is do we feel that the human mind can be adequately accounted for by the familiar laws of physics and no more? Or does the phenomenon of mind require something extra, some life force, some mystical agency, a soul, call it what you like? And depending how we answer that question, I think that will shape our answer to the artificial intelligence issue. Personally, I feel that the human mind requires nothing extra to account for it. That being so, there's no reason why an equally complex system that happened to have come from some other origin than natural evolution. For example, in other words, having been conceived and built by human beings shouldn't be capable of the same...

segments.text: All righty, let's see here.
Jackie, who's done that heater down?
I can't hear this one.
Because they're not that loud.
You say it hasn't been too cold out there?
Excuse me?
You say it hasn't been very cold out there?
No, not really. We had one slight fall of snow...
...about a week or more ago, and that was it.
It's kind of a handy place to be. We're up at about 1,800 feet, which is...
...just below the snow line. The snow line, we're in the foothills of Sierra Nevada,
so we'd get pretty high. But the snow line is something like, oh, 10 miles away.
Okay.
So you can go off in the snow if you want, but you don't have it on top of you.
where we're in the other direction if we're not that far from San Francisco.

I don't detect one now.

Uh, nope.

It's gone?

Test, test, test, test.

All righty.

Yeah.
No, it's been very mild here.
Okay.
When we first arrived, we thought it was a little chilly,
until we heard that Orlando had minus 29 the previous night,
and then we didn't think it was the chilly.
Okay, we've got the tape recorder rolling.

or how about one two three one two three looks good

gonna go ahead and get started. Okay.
Okay.
Okay.
All right.
How did you get interested in writing?
It was too long ago to remember.
When I left school at...
When I was 16 and wanted to be a writer then,
I guess it was something that I always enjoyed doing as a kid at school.
You know, the essays and the story writing exercises you get.
And when I left school, I told the world I was going to be a writer.
And it seemed a good idea until somebody said,
well, with all the accumulated wisdom and experience of 16 years,
what are you going to write about that the world is breathlessly waiting to hear?
And I hadn't thought about that.
The answer was not a lot.
So I went away into engineering and electronics and computers and things like that for something like 20 years.
And I suppose the interest in writing probably never went away.
And 20-odd years later, that situation had changed a lot.
I'd spent a lot of that time.
I started off as an electronics engineer and then a computer designer and then went into selling computer systems.
And not the blue boxes you see at work
that print out payrolls and things.
I'm not talking about business computers,
but the real-time scientific systems
that might go into scientific research laboratories
connected up to instruments to collect all the data
and turn them into pictures on screens
and the sort of computers you'd find
in particle accelerator installations or observatories.
In other words, all my customers were scientists,
physicists, biologists, chemists, and so forth.
And the kinds of systems we're talking about
ranged up to several million dollars.
And when somebody's buying a system of that size,
it's not the kind of thing that you sell
in a one-half-hour sales call and, say, sign the paper.
you're frequently working with them for 12, maybe 18 months before a contract is finalized.
During that time, you have to try and understand a lot of what they're doing
in terms of being able to put together and recommend the right sort of system for their needs.
In other words, you get to know a little bit of what they're all doing.
I found it fascinating, a fascinating world that they lived in.
the
you also get to know them socially
how they think
how they tick
what makes them laugh
very interesting as people
and I found 20 years later
that there were a lot
of interesting things
to put here
to write about
and form the basis
of stories
so
I didn't
particularly set out
to be a science fiction writer
I suppose
I became one by accident
I just
always wanted to write
and started writing stories
about the little bit of life
that I'd had some personal experience of
and was told I was a science fiction writer,
and I said, how's that?
They said, well, the publisher is publishing it
under their science fiction influence,
so we guess you have to be, so I said okay.
And it kind of started out like that.
Oh, okay.
Could you hold for just a second here?
I've got to take care of a slight flutter
in one of my machines.
Okay, hang on, I'll be right back with you.
Okay.
Still here.
Oh, okay.
you've covered a lot of the background already so
is there a problem?
I'm just getting a funny scraping noise off a reel of tape
so it's not going to be really picking up anyway
so we'll just leave it
has it gone away?
no it's sitting there just scraping away
but to heck with it
you've covered a lot of the background
stuff like I said
so I think I will go right into some other stuff
associating with
the scientist as you were
I guess that gave you a lot of the background material that you use in your stories.
Yeah. Well, that provided more the trigger.
The stimulation to take an interest in that kind of work,
I guess reading provided a lot of it.
But that kind of material is easy to read when you have a vested interest in understanding it
because you have business relationships that will profit from that understanding
In other words, it's reading with a purpose, a clear-cut purpose rather than just out of curiosity or a way of killing time.
But luckily, it became a little more than that.
Do you usually do a lot of—back up here.
Most of your stories, I guess, would be called hard science fiction.
Yeah.
Do you do a lot of research whenever you do write a story?
Yeah, I do.
I read quite a lot, and I suppose the bulk of my reading is non-fiction,
so even casual reading in a way becomes what might be termed non-specific research.
In other words, information that just gets stored away and comes out later,
although I didn't study it for any particular reason at the time.
But before I became a full-time writer, I was still working in the computer business,
I made use of my customers pretty freely as consultants, which was kind of handy.
I found that I had customers who were brain surgeons and other customers who studied pieces
of rock brought back from the Apollo missions and other guys who were building or investigating
machine intelligence.
And just about any of the topics, or the favorite themes of science fiction
that you could tick out of a hat, the chances were sort of not ten to one.
I had a customer specializing in that field, and I just had to...
If I needed some background information on a particular topic,
I could almost guarantee I had a phone number in my diary
of the guy who could talk all day about it.
And they loved doing it, as well.
I used to call them, and if they'd like to come and talk to you tomorrow,
Well we're a little busy but what's it about?
Oh I need some help with the book I'm working on.
Well why didn't you say so?
What time do you want to show up?
And they talk all day.
And I think this is one of the interesting sides of selling computers into this kind of area.
You can imagine some of these specialists they talk to bacteria all day long or whatever
and they end up shut in the back rooms of universities.
And maybe there are four people on the planet
they can talk to who understand their language.
And sometimes they find it hard to believe
that somebody from the world outside
that has walked in off the street
is sincerely interested to sit down and talk to them
and is curious,
and he wants to know what they're doing,
wants to have it explained.
And it was a very pleasant way to worth living, you not only, you know, gain customers in
many instances, I found you gain friends as well.
It was a very pleasant combination to build a life around with, the things you like doing,
the kind of work that you like to
the kind of activity that you like to do is also
part of a process of making friends and not only that
somebody's prepared to pay you to do it
I found that a very pleasant situation
Your first novel, in fact I believe
it was the first thing that you wrote was in A Hair of the Stars
it's a science fiction detective story
Yes.
How did you come to write that book?
Well, I think that sums it up pretty well.
It reflects, I think, the way I see science,
which is indeed as a wonderful, ongoing, never-ending detective story.
and I suppose I got a little bit dissatisfied
with some of the depictions of science and scientists
that I'd seen in fiction.
I formed the impression or the suspicion in some cases
that perhaps the people who had written some of the fiction
certainly would have perhaps not worked in a scientific field
or spoken to a scientist for a long, long time
and maybe generations of people had reinforced each other's clichés.
Scientists were always eccentric and they wore odd-coloured shoes
and they drew cabbages that ate people
and they wanted to conquer the world or something.
There were these cute public impressions of scientists
just as people who run down the street with no clothes off,
shouting Eureka,
or,
you read phrases like,
it came to him in a flash,
and you read on,
and what came to him in a flash
would have been enough to keep Einstein busy
for the next 20 years,
and real science,
yeah, there are insights,
There are strokes of genius, but the overwhelming bulk of the work is done by a lot of unsung heroes,
a lot of people doing nothing really dramatic or exciting,
but just meticulously sifting through details and collecting information
for generations and for centuries or different parts of the world.
And it's really like putting together a huge jigsaw puzzle,
Lots of people cutting out pieces and twisting them around.
Every now and again somebody will take a huge chunk in this corner
and see that it fits with a huge chunk down there.
And that's a breakthrough.
And so it goes on.
And it really is a detective story.
I think it's a far more exciting one than most detective fiction.
And I wanted to write a story that attempted to depict it in this kind of way
and hopefully would convey some of the excitement that personally I feel
when I look at this whole scene.
Yeah, I believe...
I think that...
I thought that, yeah, let's make it a detective story,
but if we...
If we want a detective mystery
that is going to be
sufficiently intriguing
to motivate a large proportion
of the scientific community
as happened in Inherit the Stars,
we want something a little more
original and exciting
than bodies in the library or footprints in the flower bed.
So we invented Charlie and the aliens,
and the rest I suppose you know.
Basically it was an attempt to depict science as it is,
or at least as I perceive it.
And at the same time weave that into a story
that people who were non-scientists, non-specialists,
would find stimulating and arousing for the curiosity
even if, you know, without trying to turn it into a 250-page lab report or something like that.
Yeah, I believe, I don't know if I'm reading this into your work or not,
but some of what I'm feeling is that your writing is sort of almost a celebration of learning,
you know, the learning process.
Yes.
I think it's one of the most exciting processes anybody can experience.
I think it's very sad that in large sections of our culture
we should have evolved the attitude that learning is something
you endure until you leave school,
and then it ceases without output.
I think education and living are just different aspects
of the same process that never ends in the minds of a lot of people the two
things seem to have separated out and for some reason learning is looked upon
as hard work and something that you you steer clear of unless you
can't avoid it I think that's very very sad no reason why it should be so it's
just a consequence of cultural expectations a lot of people expect it
to be hard work and tedious
and sure enough it is.
In your stories,
I've noticed that you
really flesh out the futures
that you create with a lot of detail.
Uh-huh.
I lost my question.
You were saying
about the future
of detail.
Yeah, let me just rephrase it here.
I notice in your stories
that you really fleshed them out
with a lot of detail.
That's simply to just make the story more realistic.
I don't know that there's any particular purpose in doing that.
I try and use as much detail as I feel is needed
to convey whatever meaning I'm trying to convey
at that particular part of the book.
some
in fact some parts I
got over very quickly because
there's really not a lot to say
if
I don't know if you have any specific examples
in mind that we could talk about
more particularly but
I remember and one
I think the short answer is I
simply make descriptions etc
as detailed as I feel they need
to be to say what I want to say
Yeah, I was remembering one particular instance when a hunt is traveling from England to the United States.
And he opens up his briefcase and plugs in his video phone to the plane and makes this long-distance call right there.
It seems so natural that it just creates a very realistic atmosphere for your story.
Yeah, I like to do things like that.

I see what you mean by detail now. I think these kinds of details do matter because if we're putting a story into a futuristic setting, I think these little details of background, such as if the guy needs to make a phone tour, how does he go about it if he needs to rent a cab?
these matter because
if the story is being told in the future
the whole of the background
has to be consistently futuristic
I've come across a number
of instances which in my opinion
are a little flawed because
felt with an
A.W.
A writer may have
seized on a particular
thought, maybe a new scientific
idea or a machine
or whatever.
Develops that very well,
but kind of gets hung up on it
and in the background,
everything else that's going on
hasn't changed since 1980.
And trying to, I think,
just stop typing for the five minutes it takes
just to think about a situation.
The guy's going to make a phone call
just like stop and think how he might make that
and think about it for five minutes
and then maybe show it in a way different
to what would have been the impulsive thing to do
in the first couple of seconds.
It's worth the effort.
I don't think it radically changes the story,
but it does give it that finishing polish, as it were,
at least in that sense.
And I try to do this in all the stories,
and I find that readers like it.

I think I, from the people who write to me and the people that I meet, one of the gratifying things I observe in the readership that I have is that very, it is not confined to what might be termed a hardcore science fiction reader who buys anything new that appears on the science fiction section of the bookstores.
But a lot of, I suppose, people who might be termed younger professional people in their late 20s, 30s, 40s,
in all manner of professions, not necessarily to do with the sciences, teachers, lawyers, doctors, so forth,
who typically would say, gee, I used to read science fiction when I was at college or when I was at university,
but I kind of grew out of it.
I can't relate to way out galaxies
like years away anymore
or aliens running around with ray guns
today I have a family, a career
a mortgage, my feet are solidly
on the surface of this planet
but they seem to like
stories that
don't kind of try and take them to the other side
of the universe a million years from now
but maybe just stretch the future 20 or 30 years
and they find names
in the book like IBM
and Davis and Boeing
familiar places, and it grabs them. I say, well, this I can relate to. It's
the world that I live in just stretched a little bit. The connection is not
broken. The economics and the politics have evolved from what I read in the
papers. I can still see the connections, and it could be the world my kids grow up
in. And I like it, and if it has that effect on that, you know, far
vast and a market of readership, then I'm perfectly happy to continue
doing that, in addition to the reason that I enjoy the stories better myself for doing that.
I wouldn't be misreading and saying you're an optimistic person, would I?
I think I am.
I notice your stories tend to be rather optimistic.
Sure. Why not?
Good question. Why not?
I think there's enough doom and gloom around.
I try and contribute something to counterbalance all that.
I think it's needed.
You probably would hold a great hope for the human potential then.
Excuse me? I missed a question.
You probably would hold a great hope for the human potential.
Oh, I think it's unlimited.
it doesn't
guarantee we'll
use
it correctly
and wisely. There's no
guarantee of that, but I have
no doubt that the potential exists
and the choice is entirely up
to us. And I think
that in itself is grounds for optimism.
It means that we're not pawns
that are pushed around by fate
or magical
mystical forces
that we have no control over
our future.
I think that would be
a very depressing thought.
I think it underlies
a lot of the philosophies
that we hear expounded.
You know, an excuse
to quit trying,
to write everything off
as futile.
I don't subscribe
to this at all.
I think that
in the same way
that the individual's future
lies in his or her hands,
and I think they have
infinite potential
to build upon if they have a, I think the only resource that we're short of in some
quarters is positive thinking and the right attitude of mind.
Nothing else.
And I think collectively the same is true.
I think that there is a human tendency to be too conscious of our failings and our faults
and our mistakes, which have happened.
It would be silly to deny that.
And I think, by and large, we've achieved some remarkable and wonderful things as well
and continue to do so.
And I think when I look at the bottom line of the balance sheet,
I'm pretty proud to be a member of the human race.
Okay, we're just commenting on here.
I happen to agree with you.
hold for just a second here we're going to shut the machine down zero just said go
ahead and continue he just stopped and I had just stopped the machine to find out
what it was that he said that was sort of redundant on my part
okay machines cranked back up and we're rolling again okay in your novel
twice upon a time you based the story around a device that can send messages
is back in time.
Yes.
To itself, 24 hours in the past.
Sure.
And then, by that process,
just keep sending it back to itself
and back to itself.
Uh-huh.
I've been reading recently
about several scientists
who are speculating about
real possibilities of time travel.
Yeah.
Was your novel...
Your novel really was written
before those came out.
It's sort of prophetic in a way.
Maybe that's where they got it from.
Well, I don't know whether it's prophetic or not.
Well, as is elaborated in the book itself,
if something like that ever became a fact,
there are some pretty interesting problems that are going to have to be solved,
and our ideas of logic and cause and effect
are going to have to undergo some pretty interesting revisions.
So I'm certainly not setting myself up as a prophet and saying,
yes, it'll happen.
Maybe. I don't know.
I think history has shown that
impossible or it'll never happen
are very dangerous phrases
to use in any context.
As far as I was concerned,
it was just a fun basis for a story,
certainly not an original one.
Although I did, I was trying,
I don't suppose any of the things
I've written about
have been original in essence.
I try and approach them
from hopefully fresh
and different angles.
But for some time,
And for a number of years, in fact,
before I wrote Thrice Upon a Time,
I'd been wanting to write a Time Shavet book
for a number of reasons.
Firstly, I wanted to attempt to face up to the paradoxes,
the logical paradoxes, once and for all,
and answer them without cop-outs,
without convenient coincidences,
and without obliging characters
who just happen to do the right thing
to make everything come out the way the author said.
And secondly, I wanted to get away from this kind of cliche
of some kind of a conjurer's box described or disguised as whatever
that you jump into and you jump out of and you're in some other time.
We've seen too many conjurer's boxes, and it seemed to me unrealistic.
If I ever build a box like that,
and I thought it was going to take me to another time,
I certainly wouldn't jump into it and press the button.
I would conduct a long series of tests and experiments first,
and none of that heroes ever seem to do this.
And it seemed to me reasonable to say,
if we're going to make the speculation of influencing the past,
it seemed to me to be reasonable to speculate
that if we're going to make that assumption anyway,
that before we move structured objects and people
back into another time,
we probably learn how to inject energy first.
And if you can send energy back in time,
you can obviously switch the energy on and off
and modulate it and send information.
In other words, you can send messages
to yourself if you like.
I didn't want it to be a million years
or a billion years
or in some huge span of time where really nothing that you did could make any difference.
How about a lab bench experiment?
Ten minutes.
You can just send a little signal back to yourself.
Ten minutes ago would change what you've already done.
This is interesting.
You're hard up against the paradoxes now.
You can't find a way around them or duck them.
You've got to answer the question, what happened?
But the logic of it, the whole situation becomes absolutely,
it drives you to the point of insanity trying to figure it out.
I found the only way to do it was to think in terms of the simplest possible lab bench experiment
that you could devise and strip away all the complications to just get the logic right
and then elaborate it back in up to the level that would make a story interesting.
And the simplest situation that you can think of is a button and a lamp.
and when you push the button, the lamp comes on.
It couldn't get much simpler than that.
The only different thing here is
the lamp comes on 10 seconds before you press the button
because the signal goes back in time.
So the question is obvious.
What happens?
I wait until the lamp comes on.
10 seconds later, it's time to press the button.
You're not going to press it.
Nobody could make me.
I didn't want mystical forces compelling people to do something they didn't want to do.
I wanted to preserve human free will.
So what happens?
I don't press it up.
Conversely, I can say, well, the lamp didn't come on.
But I'm going to press it up anyway, just to hell of it.
What happened?
So those are two situations.
One being the inverse of the other.
And if you can explain what happens, you can answer any time travel paradox because every one is an elaboration of one of those situations or the other.
And it's not good enough to, for example, to wait for the lamp to come on and you say,
you're not going to press the button and you fold your arms and sit there.
And just as the time is up, the door opens and somebody strolls in and says, hey, what's this?
And presses the button.
That doesn't get you out of it because you're a scientist.
you're going to repeat your experiment
under conditions where that couldn't happen.
You'd lock the door and set it up again.
You'd go out of the room
and have the computer press the button.
But eventually you would test it
time and time and time again.
And if accidents happened
that got you out of a mess the first time,
you could eliminate them the next time.
And eventually you have to face up
to that question, what happened?
That's what I wanted to do.
And the third thing I wanted to do
was to tell a story in which
the time machine itself
and the staggering conceptual changes
in physics and philosophy
that are implied
are relevant to the story
that's being told
they're an integral part of it
if you took them away
there wouldn't be any story
I think in too many stories
time machines are used
like starships
they're just a device
a vehicle
to get characters
into an unusual environment
and then tell a pretty routine story that was stolen from Greek mythology
or European medieval history.
And the technology doesn't come into the story at all.
They could have gone there on a greyhound bus.
I didn't want to do that.
And so the story was about some physicists
who had stumbled upon this phenomenon
and had realized that if what they were seeing
meant what they thought it meant,
it meant that they could actually inject information into the past,
change the past, with all the questions that implies.
And they proceeded to test this phenomenon
and have paid some very, very strange results.
And yet they're convinced that behind all this,
there is some consistent system of super logic that does make sense,
and they're trying to figure out the rules of it.
And of course there's an unspoken
or unwritten invitation for the reader to participate.
And again, I suppose it's a kind of a detective story.
Not so much a whodunit, but how is it done?
To see if the reader can figure out the rules
before the characters do.
It is something that I noticed
when I was reading the novel
is that there are no unresolved paradoxes in it.
You do sew them all up neatly
before the end of the novel
Well, that was one of the goals of writing the book.
Yeah.
And I think it worked because the people who seem to know what they're talking about
and have commented seem pretty satisfied.
So that made me pretty satisfied.
There are a couple of silly things in there which don't really affect the physics of the time machine.
There was a big fusion plant up in Scotland.
and uh i don't know why due to a lapse of concentration on my part in one chapter it
had moved to another part of Scotland we'll fix that when the book next reprinted
it was an eagle-eyed Scotsman wrote to me and picked that out
yeah it started off on the Solway Firth and ended up on the Murray Firth or no the other way around
i i got it on the wrong first in one chapter well maybe uh for one of your future novels
you have to explore matter transmitters.
Yeah, that's another possibility.
I did explore that in a short story I wrote called Assassin,
which was in the Stellar Anthology series, Stellar number 4.
This was exploring the possibility of matter transmission
and of course people.
You can instantly get somebody from here to there,
but in fact what appears there is a copy of them,
so that you've now got two of them.
If the other one decides to come back the same way,
you're getting rapidly multiplying problems, literally.
Tell Assassin was a story that played around with that thought.
I must have missed that one.
Since Tellur 4, it came out a couple of years ago.
Okay.
You've written a sequel to Inherit the Stars
called The Gentle Giants of Ganymede.
That's right.
Did you intend to follow the story in Inherit the Stars with a sequel, or was that from reader demand or what?
A bit of both.
When I wrote Inherit the Stars, I had three books in mind.
I had a trilogy in mind.
So I put the hooks in.
Although Inherit the Stars was a complete story in itself, it didn't leave the reader hanging.
It started and told and finished a story.
Nevertheless, there were a couple of hooks in there that invited some questions,
which sort of, as it were, paved the way to a follow-up book.
And my thinking at the time was, I'll go that far,
but I won't write the second book until I have some feedback
as to how the readers liked the first one.
And I got a lot of mail and they all liked it,
and a lot of them said in their letters,
will there be a follow-up, they picked out the hooks, so I wrote The Gentle Giants.
And they wanted another one, and I did have a trilogy in mind when I wrote it, and the
third one in that series is now written.
It's called Giant Star, and it's a July title, so it should start to appear in the
bookstores around June.
It's the third and last.
There won't be any more in that series.
so it ties up a few
of the loose ends
tells another story
continues
with the characters we met
in the previous two books
